text: I never saw a notice of deposition.
- - - EXAMINATION
Good morning, Ms. Chour.
speaker: MR. MANARA

text: Chour.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Good morning, Ms. Chour.  My name is Michael Manara.  I represent Andrea Baxter for a car accident that occurred February 6th of 2017. We are here today to take your deposition.
speaker: MR. MANARA

text: Okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Have you ever been deposed before?
speaker: MR. MANARA

text: Never.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: A couple ground rules before we begin. A deposition is a question-and-answer session.  It's not designed to trick or confuse you.  We're just trying to find out what happened.
speaker: MR. MANARA

text: Okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You're testifying here today through an interpreter?
speaker: MR. MANARA

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You're being responsive to my questions?
speaker: MR. MANARA

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: No problem.

text: It seems like you do understand some English?

text: Some.

text: Answer in your native language, and allow the interpreter to interpret, okay?
speaker: MR. MANARA

text: Okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: A couple of ground rules for the deposition.  First, I need you to answer verbally.  As you can see, there is a court reporter here typing down everything we're saying, and she can't take any head nods or hand gestures.
speaker: MR. MANARA

text: Okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Same with uh-uh and uh-huh.  I don't think it should be a problem because we have the interpreter, but they read the same way on the record.  If we ask is that a yes or is that a no, we just want to make it clear, okay?
speaker: MR. MANARA

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: If at any time I'm speaking too fast or you need me to rephrase the question or you don't understand the question, let me know, and I'll be happy to rephrase the question.
speaker: MR. MANARA

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Because if you answer my question, I will assume two very important things; one, that you understood the question; two, the answer is the truth; is that fair?
speaker: MR. MANARA

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you understand the oath you took today is the same oath you'd take in a courtroom?
speaker: MR. MANARA

text: Yes.

speaker: MR. MANARA

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

speaker: MR. MANARA

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

speaker: MR. MANARA

text: Yes.

speaker: MR. MANARA

speaker: MR. MANARA

text: Just to make sure she understands your question.  Is there any reason why she can't?  There is many reasons why she can't. Why don't you ask the question first, and then she can address if she's able to answer that accurately and truthfully. On behalf of my client, yes, if she understands the question. Is that fair enough?

text: No.

text: You rephrase then.
speaker: MR. LOMBARDO

text: It's probably something that they want to see to look at the pictures or whatever they took, if there is anything that affects inside the bones or anything that would cause the pain or discomfort.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you go to that bone place?
speaker: MR. MANARA

text: I didn't.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Is there a reason why you didn't go?
speaker: MR. MANARA

text: Because I was thinking I don't think there is any broken bone or fractures in my body.  I didn't think I would need to go see any bone doctor.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Ma'am, have you paid anything out of pocket as a result of this accident?
speaker: MR. MANARA

text: Objection as to form.
speaker: MR. LOMBARDO

text: Yeah, but I didn't think it was a big deal to mention it.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What did you pay?
speaker: MR. MANARA

text: Some medicines for pain and stuff like that that I need to take when I feel pain.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Are these over the counter or prescription?
speaker: MR. MANARA

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you know how much?
speaker: MR. MANARA

text: A couple dollars each time.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Counsel, I have the PIP is not exhausted.
speaker: MR. MANARA

text: I'm not 100 percent sure of that.
speaker: MR. LOMBARDO

text: Ma'am, did you own the car?
speaker: MR. MANARA

text: Not before, never.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: The car you were in at the accident, did you own that car?
speaker: MR. MANARA

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: At the time of the accident, did you own a car?
speaker: MR. MANARA

text: No, not that time.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Counsel, is there a consortium claim?
speaker: MR. MANARA

text: No consortium claim.
speaker: MR. LOMBARDO

text: Ma'am, very briefly I would just like to do a quick pain scale with you, okay?  10 would be the worst pain you've ever experienced in your entire life, and 0 would be no pain at all. Does that make sense?
speaker: MR. MANARA

text: Okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You indicated to me earlier you injured your neck down your right arm and your lower back.
speaker: MR. MANARA

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Discussing your neck, when you first started to feel pain in your neck, how would you rate that pain?
speaker: MR. MANARA

text: About 5 and 6.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: At the end of treatment in September of 2017, how would you rate the pain to your neck?
speaker: MR. MANARA

text: It's better, around 3 and 4.  It's still there.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: As you sit here today, how would you rate the pain to your neck?
speaker: MR. MANARA

text: Around 2 or 3, because as I'm sitting for a certain amount of time, I still feel some numbness sensation there.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Discussing your right arm, does that right arm pain travel from your neck, or is it actually your shoulder?
speaker: MR. MANARA

text: It's separate from the neck.  No traveling from there.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: The pain in your neck stayed in your neck?
speaker: MR. MANARA

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: The pain in your right shoulder, did that travel anywhere or stay in your right shoulder?
speaker: MR. MANARA

text: Just pain down to my right shoulder from the right shoulder and arms.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Your lower back, did that stay in your lower back or travel anywhere?
speaker: MR. MANARA

text: No, it stayed there.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Discussing your right arm, when you first started to feel pain in your right arm, how would you rate the pain in your right arm?
speaker: MR. MANARA

text: About same number as the neck.  The problem is this with the neck:  When I take the medicine, the pain would go away.  It helped relieve the pain.  But in terms of the shoulder, it doesn't seem to go away.  It doesn't seem to help much with medicine.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You indicated when you first started to feel pain, it was the same as your neck, about a 5 or 6?
speaker: MR. MANARA

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: At the end of treatment, how would you rate the pain to your right arm and shoulder area?
speaker: MR. MANARA

text: Around 2 or 3.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: As you sit here today, how would you rate the pain to your right arm and shoulder area?
speaker: MR. MANARA

text: Around 2.  That is just sitting, not doing anything, not making much movement or not lifting anything.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How about lifting things and making movement, how would you rate that pain to your right arm/shoulder area?
speaker: MR. MANARA

text: Not the same as when I was first injured, up to about 4 to 5.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Discussing your low back, how would you rate your pain to your low back when you first started to feel pain?
speaker: MR. MANARA

text: Around 4 when it start.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: At the end of treatment in September of 2017, how would you rate the pain to your low back?
speaker: MR. MANARA

text: Around 1 or 2.  That's if I'm not doing anything, lifting, or bending so much.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: As you sit here today, how would you rate the pain in your low back?
speaker: MR. MANARA

text: Around 1 or 2.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: When you're moving and bending, is it worse?
speaker: MR. MANARA

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How would you rate it when it gets worse when you're lifting and bending?
speaker: MR. MANARA

text: Not as much, around 3 and 4.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Ma'am, I understand you didn't get out of the car on scene. Did you ever see the rear of the car you were in after the accident?
speaker: MR. MANARA

text: No.  I got so scared and nervous at the time.  I just wanted to get home and rush to get home and go and relax.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: After you got home following the accident, maybe not that day, maybe within the week or month, did you ever see the back of the car you were in at the time of the accident?
speaker: MR. MANARA

text: No, I did not.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You never took any pictures of the rear of the car you were involved in because you never saw it after the accident, right?
speaker: MR. MANARA

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Ma'am, did this accident affect your life in any way?
speaker: MR. MANARA

text: Yeah, of course a little bit here and there.  It did affect of what I can do.  I have to restrict myself from doing stuff that I used to, like moving, picking things up, lifting certain things, stocking certain things, stuff that every day that I'm used to I couldn't do much.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: First, as a result of this accident, is there anything that you physically cannot do anymore?
speaker: MR. MANARA

text: Well, it's more like I can still do some of them, but I would need help.  I can't do it by myself.  I will always have to ask for help.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I'll get to that.  I'll ask you what you have difficulty doing later. I want to know if there is anything, as a result of this accident, you cannot do?
speaker: MR. MANARA

text: No, not like that.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: As a result of this accident, is there anything you have difficulty doing?
speaker: MR. MANARA

text: Well, it's mainly just that I can't do anything heavy.  I most often have to ask for help all the time when I have to do certain things that I can't do by myself.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What are those things you can't do by yourself?
speaker: MR. MANARA

text: Just mainly at work.  I would always need someone else to come and help me carry certain things, lift up certain things, do certain things.  At home, I just do some housework, chores, and stuff like that, little things.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: When you say you have some difficulty carrying, what part of your body hurts when you're carrying these things at work?
speaker: MR. MANARA

text: Like if I try to lift up sodas or soda case stocks to put in a certain location at nighttime, I will start to feel very numbness to my shoulders through my arm and lower back, feeling a lot of discomfort.  So I have to take medicine to help.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: That lifting, how much weight in pounds do you have difficulty lifting?
speaker: MR. MANARA

text: I really don't know how to estimate. I don't know the estimation of what soda product, how much it weighs.  I go and see it and I try to lift it, and I realize it's heavy and hurting me.  I ask for help.  I never know in advance how much certain things weigh.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You said earlier about a soda case?
speaker: MR. MANARA

text: Well, I know it's a soda case.  I don't know how many bottles of soda are in that.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you have any difficulty doing housework?
speaker: MR. MANARA

text: Well, I manage a little cooking here and there, not much of any lifting, mainly a woman's job.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you have any difficulty cooking?
speaker: MR. MANARA

text: I'm okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you have any difficulty taking care of yourself, meaning getting dressed, using the restroom, showering, feeding yourself?
speaker: MR. MANARA

text: I'm okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Other than that carrying and lifting, do you have any difficulty doing anything else as a result of this accident?
speaker: MR. MANARA

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you go to the gym at all?
speaker: MR. MANARA

text: No, I never did.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Never did, not even before the accident?
speaker: MR. MANARA

text: Never ever.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you go to church or have any activities for religion?
speaker: MR. MANARA

text: Once in a while, like do Cambodian New Years, stuff like that.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Any difficulties celebrating at church or any religious function as a result of this accident?
speaker: MR. MANARA

text: No, because I don't really involve much of doing any activity.  I just go, make some donation and mainly go home.  I don't really do anything to help.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Is that the same as it was before the accident, or did it change?
speaker: MR. MANARA

text: The same.  I don't do anything different.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Have you traveled anywhere since the accident?
speaker: MR. MANARA

text: I don't remember.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you get married in Cambodia?
speaker: MR. MANARA

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you travel to Cambodia, I'm assuming, for the wedding?
speaker: MR. MANARA

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: That was in 2018?
speaker: MR. MANARA

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Any difficulties traveling to Cambodia or getting married in 2018 as a result of this accident?
speaker: MR. MANARA

text: Well, yes, of course, there is some very discomfort, some pain here and there because it's a long flight.  I have to sit for a long period of time, and also the ceremony is difficult.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you have any accommodations at your ceremony in Cambodia as a result of this accident?
speaker: MR. MANARA

text: Well, I told them to just limit the time, not to do everything, not to take too long because it's a very long wedding because of my discomfort.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How long was the flight to Cambodia?
speaker: MR. MANARA

text: Over 20 hours.  I can't remember exactly how many.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How long was the wedding?
speaker: MR. MANARA

text: The flight, right?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: No, the wedding, the actual wedding.
speaker: MR. MANARA

text: Well, there is a portion of the ceremony in the evening the night before, and then in the morning throughout the day. There is different parts of the ceremony that takes from the day before into the next day and evening.  There is a ceremony and reception the next day, as well.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Ma'am, that's all I have for you. Thank you.
speaker: MR. MANARA

text: Counsel, while we're here on the record, I would just ask if you could send me the notice of deposition you sent to my client that you previously provided. I think you said you faxed it, so I'll just ask for a fax confirmation, the e-mail you sent.  If you sent it certified mail, I would ask for that, as well. I just don't have it.  I've never seen it.  The only correspondence I have wasn't a notice of deposition.
speaker: MR. MANARA

text: I understand.
speaker: MR. LOMBARDO
